title: 106_s2748
content: The Act may be cited as the "Russian-American Trust and Cooperation Act of 2000". The Congress finds that the Russian Federation operates an intelligence facility at Lourdes, Cuba, leased for $100-300 million a year, which is used for intelligence activities against the United States. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, leased by the Russian Federation for $100-300 million a year, is the largest complex operated by Russia outside the former Soviet Union. Covering a 28 square-mile area, it houses over 1,500 personnel and has multiple tracking dishes and a satellite system for intercepting communications. The Lourdes facility in Cuba, leased by the Russian Federation, has multiple tracking dishes and a satellite system used for intercepting communications, including telephone calls, faxes, and computer communications. The facility has been reported to collect sensitive information about United States military operations and personal information about US citizens in both private and government sectors. The Lourdes espionage station in Cuba, leased by the Russian Federation, collects personal information about US citizens and is used for cyberwarfare against the United States. The facility's operational significance grew after a directive from Russian President Boris Yeltsin in 1996 to gather Western economic and trade secrets. The Russian government has reportedly spent over $3 billion on the facility's operation and modernization. The Russian government has reportedly spent over $3 billion on the operation and modernization of the Lourdes facility in Cuba. Former US officials confirm the expansion and upgrade of the facility, with a high-ranking Russian military delegation visiting Cuba to discuss its operation. The Russian Federation is prohibited from bilateral debt rescheduling and forgiveness. The President is prohibited from rescheduling or forgiving any outstanding bilateral debt owed by the Government of the Russian Federation until they cease operations at the intelligence facility in Lourdes, Cuba. The President may waive this prohibition with congressional certification. The President is prohibited from forgiving Russian debt until they close the intelligence facility in Cuba. The President can waive this with congressional certification. The President can waive the prohibition on forgiving Russian debt with congressional certification, including a detailed description of the reasons for the waiver. The President must also submit periodic reports every 180 days to specific committees in Congress. The President must submit periodic reports every 180 days to specific congressional committees on the extent to which the requirements are being met. SEC. 4. REPORT ON THE CLOSING OF THE INTELLIGENCE FACILITY AT LOURDES, CUBA. The President must submit reports every 120 days detailing Russia's actions to close the intelligence facility in Cuba and efforts by US agencies to verify these actions.
